sen.j: 放免（ほうめん）とは日本の令外官である検非違使の下部（しもべ）を指す名称。
sen.e: Homen was the name of a shimobe (miscellaneous servants and attendants) of the kebiishi (officials with judicial and police powers) which were Ryoge no kan (a post outside the original Ritsuryo code created by Imperial edicts) in Japan.

sen.e: Homen was the name of Shimobe (miscellaneous servants and attendants) of Kebiishi (a official with judicial and police power) which was Ryoge no kan (a post outside the original Ritsuryo code created by Imperial edicts) in Japan.

sen.j: 検非違使庁の下級刑吏として、実際に犯罪者を探索し、捕縛したり、拷問や獄守を担当した。
sen.e: Homen served as a minor officer in Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief), and practically took charge of searching, capturing, and torturing the criminals and a prison guard.
Homen served as a lower-level executioner in Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief), and practically took charge of searching, capturing, and torturing criminals; and guarding a prison.

sen.j: 放免の存在は、文献によると少なくとも11世紀前半には確実に遡って確認することが出来る。
sen.e: The existence of Homen can be surely confirmed in the literature at least back in the early 11th century.
The existence of Homen can be surely confirmed in a document dated back to at least the early 11th century.

sen.j: 元々は犯罪者の情報収集などの捜査の便を考慮し、前科のある者を検非違使庁に採用したものであった。
sen.e: Originally, Kebiishicho recruited a person with a criminal record in view of convenience of investigation such as collecting information on criminals.

sen.j: 中には放免になった後も犯罪を起こしたりする者がいたようである（『今昔物語集』巻二十九「放免共、強盗ト為リ人ノ家ニ入リテ補ヘラルル語」）。
sen.e: Some homens committed crimes even after they became the homen ("Konjaku Monogatari Shu" [The Tale of Times Now Past], volume 29, 'The tale of a homen who broke in a house as a robbery and was arrested.')

sen.j: 彼らの容姿には著しい特徴が見られる。
sen.e: Their appearance had remarkable characteristics.
Their appearance had remarkable characteristics.

sen.j: 当時は一般的でなかった口髭、顎鬚を伸ばし、特殊な祭礼や一部の女子にしか許されていなかった「綾羅錦繍」、「摺衣」と呼ばれる模様の付いた衣服を身につけた。
sen.e: They had mustache and beard, which were not common in that time, and wore clothes with patterns called 'Ryorakinshu' (embroidered fine clothes) or 'Suriginu (Surigoromo)' (plant dyeing cloth) that were allowed to wear only in the special rites and festivals or only a part of women.

sen.j: この模様については、「臓物出来するところの物を染め摺り文を成した衣袴」と同時代史料に記されており、佐藤進一は検非違使の得分を示唆していると解釈している。
sen.e: This pattern was described as 'kinubakama (clothes and divided skirt) with stenciled patterns dyed by products from giblets' in the historical material about that period, and Shinichi SATO interpreted that this description suggests the profit of kebiishi.
sen.cmt: 「臓物出来するところの物」は定訳不明でしたので、「臓物から出来た物」と解釈して訳しました。

sen.j: また、七曲がりの自然木の鉾を持つ。
sen.e: Further, homen had a pike made with seven crooked natural wood.

sen.j: この鉾については僧兵の使用する撮棒などとの関連も指摘されており、いずれも穢れに対する呪術的な意味を持つものと推定されている。
sen.e: The pike is thought to have some relation to a saibo (wooden stick as a weapon) used by the sohei (warrior monk), and both are estimated to have a magical meaning against kegare (impurity.)

sen.j: これらの常民と区別される外見については、非人のため禁忌を憚らないためであるとする同時代史料があり、非人と見なされていたことが分かる。
sen.e: There is the historical material about that period describing that these appearances to be distinguished from normal people were because they were hinin (one group comprising the lowest rank in the Japanese society, often ex-convicts or vagrants) and do not avoid taboos, so it can be understood that they were considered as hinin.

sen.j: ただし当時の非人は後世とは異なり、単に差別される対象ではなく畏怖される存在であった。
sen.e: However, hinin at that period is different from hinin of after ages, and they were not only the subject to be discriminated but also the awesome existence.
